summary: This document is an email chain between Assistant U.S. Attorneys and Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys, primarily Laura Menninger, regarding the logistics of reviewing physical evidence and highly confidential materials (including nude/partially nude images) seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residences. The correspondence details negotiations over where evidence will be reviewed (500 Pearl Street courthouse vs. FBI Bronx warehouse), what can be photographed, and the schedule for Maxwell's participation. It reveals the existence of thousands of previously undisclosed 'highly confidential' images and the government's evidence handling procedures.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Lead defense counsel negotiating evidence review logistics with the prosecution. She represents Ghislaine Maxwell and makes detailed requests regarding access to physical evidence and highly confidential materials.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Copied on all defense team correspondence regarding evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Christian R Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP copied on all defense team correspondence regarding evidence review.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney copied on all correspondence regarding evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in case 20 Cr. 330. The correspondence details arrangements for her to be produced to 500 Pearl Street to review evidence with her defense team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the source of seized evidence, including electronic devices, images, and videos from his residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case (US v. Maxwell - 20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). The defense mentions seeking her permission to bring electronic devices into the courthouse.

connections.description: Menninger is lead defense counsel representing Maxwell in the criminal case, as evidenced by her negotiations for Maxwell's access to evidence.
Evidence seized from Epstein's residences is central to the case against Maxwell, indicating their prior association.
Both are members of Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team, copied on all strategic correspondence.
Both are attorneys working on Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team.
The AUSA is prosecuting the case against Maxwell and is coordinating evidence review with her defense team.

events.title: Scheduled Evidence Review at 500 Pearl Street
events.description: Planned start date for Ghislaine Maxwell and her defense team to review physical evidence and highly confidential materials at the 500 Pearl Street courthouse, contingent on Marshals' approval.

events.title: Start of Non-Testifying Witness Statement Production
events.description: The government begins producing statements from non-testifying witnesses to the defense.

events.title: FBI Searches of Epstein's Residences
events.description: The FBI seized electronic devices, images, videos, and physical items from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

events.title: Government Production of Images and Videos
events.description: The government produced images and videos seized from Epstein's devices to the defense, with a cover letter noting that nude/partially nude images were designated Highly Confidential.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (courthouse where evidence review is scheduled)
FBI Bronx Warehouse (location of most physical evidence)
26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY (FBI office where cash evidence items are held)
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Office of the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Maxwell was held and previously reviewed evidence)
Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands (source of seized evidence)
FBI Florida office (source of some investigation files and hard copy images)
keyFacts: The government disclosed approximately 2,100 previously undisclosed 'highly confidential' electronic images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices, in addition to approximately 3,400 previously reviewed images and 7 hard-copy nude images.

Physical evidence seized includes dozens of electronic devices (computers, servers, laptops), framed pictures, plaster busts of female torsos, a stuffed dog, massage tables, and cash, stored primarily at an FBI warehouse in the Bronx.

The defense team sought to review all physical evidence with Ghislaine Maxwell present at 500 Pearl Street, while the government argued transporting all items was not feasible and proposed a hybrid approach involving review at the Bronx warehouse.

Highly confidential materials containing nudity were subject to strict handling: 'Confidential' items could be photographed, while 'Highly Confidential' items generally could not be photographed without specific AUSA authorization, though non-nude portions might be photographable.

The government confirmed that all electronic media containing witness statements were from non-testifying witnesses and would be produced as digital audio files, with the original recordings also available for review.
